Department of Chemistry Lomonosov Moscow State University Leninskie Gory 1-3 Moscow 119991 Russia Graphical abstract CNT oxidation, Co/CNT preparation and transformation of both catalyst and support in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) were thoroughly studied. CNTs functionalized by nitric acid for 1–15h were used as supports for Co catalysts for FTS at 190°C and atmospheric pressure. Co supported on CNTs with the highest specific surface area and oxygen content showed the highest activity and C5+ yield. According to TEM results after 70h of FTS this catalyst was the most stable to Co sintering due to the large number of surface defects and oxygen groups on a support surface combined with the preserved integrity of CNTs. Activity of catalysts increased and selectivity to C5+ decreased when the particle size diminished from 26.5 to 4.3nm. Study of the evolution of CNT support revealed that most of the carboxylic groups decomposed at calcination. Etching of support surface during the catalyst reduction and partial pore blocking after FTS were detected. Keywords Carbon nanotubes Surface oxidation Co catalyst Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Particle size Sintering 1 Introduction Surface oxidation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) is the most commonly used method to transform hydrophobic CNT material into hydrophilic substance covered with a large number of functional groups [1]. Oxidized CNTs are used in the different areas of science and engineering such as synthesis of polymer composites [2], catalyst supports and electrochemistry [3,4]. Surface groups allow using the polar solvents during the synthesis of composites, metal and metal oxide catalysts. Various oxidizing agents, such as acids, KMnO4, H2O2, RuO4, oxygen plasma, ozone, are used for the oxidation of the CNT surface [5–7]. The most common method of CNT oxidation is the nitric acid treatment since it provides the greatest number of oxygen groups on the CNT surface [6]. The degree of CNT oxidation significantly influences the structure of CNT based composites or catalysts. Properties of CNT based composite strongly depend on the nature and number of functional groups on the CNT surface. In the case of catalysis applications, surface modification affects the metal-support interaction and stability of catalyst in different reactions [3,8]. Co based catalysts supported on CNTs are effective materials for hydrogenation of carbon oxides [9,10], electrocatalysis [11,12], catalytic oxidation of pollutants [13], hydroformylation and hydrodesulphurization reactions [4]. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is an industrial process for production of liquid fuels, lubricants and other chemicals by CO hydrogenation into hydrocarbons. Co and Fe based catalysts are commonly used in FTS. Co systems are more expensive than Fe, but at the same time more stable and less active in water gas shift reaction [14]. Oxide materials such as Al2O3, SiO2 and TiO2 are usually used as catalyst supports for FTS [15]. In the last decade CNTs have been seen as an effective alternative to oxide supports due to the lower degree of metal-support interaction, ability to tune the surface properties in a wide range, rigid structure that prevents metal agglomeration and the permanent price reduction [16–18]. FTS is highly sensitive to the structure of catalyst: porosity of support and Co particle size can significantly affect the catalytic performance [19,20]. Surface oxidation of CNTs is a powerful technique to modify the structure of CNT based catalyst. Several studies have been dedicated to the influence of CNT surface groups on the catalytic performance of Co/CNT catalysts but their results are contradictory: either positive [21] or negative [22] effects of the CNT oxidation on the activity and selectivity of catalysts were detected. In our previous work we showed that the oxidation effect can also depend on the type of CNT support and may increase or decrease the activity and selectivity of Co-based catalysts [18]. In the present study we try to assess the impact of the CNT surface state on the structure of Co/CNT catalyst for FTS and trace the evolution of support and Co at different stages of process (catalyst calcination, reduction and catalytic reaction). The main aim of this work is to reveal the effect of functionalization, defectiveness and porosity of CNT surface on the stability, activity and selectivity of Co/CNT catalyst in FTS. For this purpose CNTs are oxidized by nitric acid for different time and resulted materials are investigated as supports for Co-based FTS catalysts. Changes in Co particle size and composition/defectiveness of the support surface during the catalyst preparation, reduction and FTS are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 CNT synthesis and oxidation Multiwall CNTs were synthesized using catalytic chemical vapor deposition method via the technique described in our previous works [9,18]. Hexane and Co-Mo/MgO were used as carbon source and growth catalyst, respectively. Synthesis temperature was 750°C. Synthesized material was annealed at 400°C in air flow, washed by HCl and distilled water to remove amorphous carbon and metal impurities. Obtained sample of pristine CNTs was named as “CNTp”. CNTs were oxidized by refluxing in concentric HNO3 (Chimmed, Russia, ∼70%, density–1.4g/cm3, purity–99.999%) at acid-to-CNT ratio of ∼20ml/g under vigorous stirring (∼400rpm) for 1, 3, 6, 9, 12 and 15h. The obtained material was filtered and washed with distilled water to neutral pH and finally dried at 130°C. It was named as “CNTn” where n is the refluxing time in hours. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Catalysts were prepared by impregnation of CNT supports with Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Vecton, Russia, 99% purity) ethanol solution for metal loading of 15wt.%. After the solvent evaporation at 70°C samples were dried at 130°C for 16h. Catalysts were named as Co/CNTn (CNTp in the case of pristine CNTs). 2.3 Catalytic tests FTS was performed in a quartz tubular flow fixed bed reactor with the inner diameter of 10mm. Catalyst was placed on a layer of fiberglass fitted on a quartz grid and then reduced in situ in H2 flow (60ml/min) at 400°C for 4h. CO hydrogenation was carried out at 190°C and atmospheric pressure for 70h. Metachrom mass-flow controller was used to deliver a gas mixture of H2:CO:N2 =2:1:0.7 with the velocity of 2200ml/(hg). N2 was used as an internal standard gas. The catalyst loading was 1g. The reaction products were analyzed on an Agilent Technologies 6890N gas chromatograph. CO, N2, CH4 and CO2 gases were separated in 5m HayeSep column filled with Porapaq R and analyzed using TCD detector. Hydrocarbons were separated in 50m DB-Petro capillary column and analyzed by FID detector. CO conversion, product selectivity (S) and C5+ fraction yield (YC5+) were measured at steady state similarly to that described in Ref. [18]. TOF was calculated using TEM data for average particle size assuming spherical Co particles, with only a half of their surface being available for the reaction. 2.4 Study of CNT evolution In order to study the evolution of CNT support, additional samples of Co/CNT9 catalyst were prepared after calcination, reduction and FTS. For the calcination CNT9 support impregnated by Co nitrate was heated up to 400°C (10°/min heating rate) in nitrogen flow of 30ml/min and then slowly cooled. Reduced catalyst was prepared the same way with the additional treatment in hydrogen flow of 60ml/min for 4h at 400°C. After reduction, catalyst was slowly cooled in hydrogen flow and then passivated in O2/Ar mixture with 1vol.% of O2. Catalyst after 70h of FTS was cooled in nitrogen flow and also passivated. Obtained samples were treated with concentrated HCl solution in ultrasonic bath for 2h in order to remove Co. 2.5 Characterization Textural properties (specific surface area (SBET), average pore radius (RBJH) and total pore volume (V)) were measured by nitrogen adsorption using Quantachrome AUTOSORB-1C/MS/TPR gas sorption analyzer. Prior to analysis, samples were degassed at 250°С for 3h under vacuum. Raman spectra were registered using LabRam HR800 UV (Horiba Jobin Yvon, Japan) microscope-spectrometer using 5mW argon laser excitation with 514.5nm wavelength and 50×Olympus lens. The chemical composition of the surface and the nature of chemical bonds were determined using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) with a monochromatic Al Kα source (hν =1486.6eV, 150W). The pass energy of the analyzer was 160eV for the survey spectra and 20eV for the high-resolution ones. X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded using a Stoe Stadi P instrument equipped with Ni-filtered CuKα X-ray tube in the 2θ range from 10 to 70°. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed on a home-made system that consisted of a gas preparation stage, quartz reactor, tube furnace and TCD-detector. Gas mixture (Ar+5% H2) at a flow rate of 23ml/min was used for the reduction. Heating rate was 12°/min. Before XRD and TPR analyzes catalysts were heated to 400°C (10°/min heating rate) in nitrogen flow of 30ml/min and then slowly cooled. Morphology of the catalysts was studied using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 2100F). Samples for TEM study were reduced in hydrogen (60ml/min) for 4h at 400°C and then passivated in O2/Ar mixture with 1vol.% of O2. Catalysts after reaction were also passivated before TEM analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CNT oxidation TEM images of CNTp, CNT6 and CNT15 are shown in Supplementary material (S1). Oxidation of CNTs gradually destroys their walls (Fig. S1b) which finally results in highly damaged material (Fig. S1c). This trend is common for the oxidation of CNTs by liquid nitric acid that was shown elsewhere [21,23–26]. The changes in the textural properties of CNTs during oxidation are presented in Fig. 1 a. SBET value shows a maximum at 9h of oxidation due to defects formation on the surface and then decreases probably because of the strong destruction of CNTs. Similar trend was observed in the oxidation of N-doped CNTs for 2–20h, but the maximum SBET was found at 2h of oxidation [26]. Such a difference in the position of maximum SBET can be explained by higher defectiveness of N-doped CNTs (see below the discussion of Raman data): oxidation of more defective tubes takes less time. Pore volume maximum at 1h in the present study corresponds to the opening of CNT channels, partial cutting of nanotubes and removing of residual growth catalyst [23]. Further decrease of pore volume during oxidation is explained by the compaction of CNTs due to affinity of functional groups to each other. Raman spectroscopy is one of the most commonly used method to trace structural changes of carbon materials during oxidation [25]. The intensity ratio of D and G bands (ID/IG, see Supplementary material, S2) is usually used as a parameter describing the structure disorder in carbon materials. According to TEM data (Fig. S1) the surface layers of CNTs are partially destroyed after oxidation. Destroying and cutting of CNTs lead to the appearance of edge carbon atoms. ID/IG ratio change represents the increase in the defectiveness of CNTs during oxidation (Fig. 1b). This ratio stabilizes after 9h of oxidation since the rate of the formation of new defects is completely compensated by the rate of total destruction of defective CNTs. ID/IG ratio for CNTs in the present work is in the range of ∼0.95–1.25 which confirms their less defective structure comparing with N-CNTs, for which ID/IG ratio was found to be 1.7–2.2 [26]. Raman spectroscopy can also be used to control the purity of CNTs using the intensity of the band at ∼500cm−1 (Fig. S2) which corresponds to the presence of residual CoO from the growth catalyst [27]. Ratio of the intensity of this band to the intensity of G band (ICoO/IG) was chosen as a parameter which characterizes CoO impurities in studied CNTs (Fig. 1b). It was found that the content of CoO actually decreases during oxidation. After 12h of treatment CoO is almost completely removed. As this intensity ratio characterizes only CoO impurity, Co and Mo carbides may still exist in CNTs. ICoO/IG ratio may be also used for the characterization of CNT supported Co based catalysts. The increase in oxygen content in CNTs is observed up to 9h of oxidation (XPS data in Fig. 1c). After that the rates of the formation of oxygen-containing functional groups and their transformation into CO2 become equal which results in the stabilization of oxygen content on the surface of CNTs. Kinetics of CNT oxidation is shown in Fig. 1c and corresponds to the reaction: C+4HNO3 → CO2 + 4NO2 +2H2O It may be noted that according to SBET, Raman, XPS and mass loss data the most intense oxidation occurs during the first 3h of acid treatment. Thus, the transformations on the CNT surface seem to be as follows. Firstly, upper wall is partially oxidized. Then the surface gets saturated by functional groups, with the surface oxygen content reaching the highest values. Finally, some carbon atoms leave the surface as CO2 with the simultaneous oxidation of the next graphene layer. No change in oxygen content is observed at this stage. Depending on the defectiveness of individual nanotube all these processes take place at different time for each particular nanotube. More intensive oxidation of CNTs occurs during first 3h as the most defective sites in CNTs are rapidly oxidized. 3.2 Co/CNT structure characterization Samples CNTp, CNT1, CNT3, CNT9 and CNT15 were loaded by 15wt.% of Co. XRD patterns of all unreduced annealed catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 a. Two phases are identified in each sample: Co3O4 and CNTs. Co oxide peaks become wider for the catalysts with more oxidized support as a result of the decreasing of the crystallite size. TPR profiles of all catalysts and two supports (CNTp and CNT15) are shown in Fig. 2b. Carbon materials are well known to react with hydrogen at high temperatures with the formation of methane [28]. In our case there is a strong difference between TPR profiles of CNTp and CNT15. CNT15 consumes H2 at higher temperatures than CNTp whereas the profile for the latter shows more than one process. This can be explained by residual impurities of both amorphous carbon and growth catalyst in CNTp. Reduction of intratubular Co oxide and carbide particles from CNT growth catalyst and methanation of carbon material overlap resulting in a complex form of TPR profile. The presence of CNT growth catalyst in the samples leads to the local overheating near metal, oxide or carbide particles, which may be another reason of the decreasing of H2 uptake temperature of CNTp. This fact also explains the shift of methanation towards lower temperatures in case of Co/CNT15 and other catalysts supported on oxidized CNTs. Fu et al. detected the increase in H2 consumption in Co/N-CNT catalysts after the oxidation of support and attributed it to the catalytic effect of Co particles [26]. They suggested that smaller Co particles were more active in the promotion of direct CNT methanation. It is known that oxidized carbon surface releases CO/CO2 during heating [29]. Since Co catalyzes hydrogenation of these gases, CO/CO2 methanation on Co catalyst may also take place but its contribution to the overall methanation is hard to separate from the methanation of bulk CNTs. In CNT15 TPR profile the small peaks at 200–500°C are also observed. They correspond to H2 uptake caused by the reduction of functional groups on the CNT surface [29]. According to XRD, all cobalt in Co/CNT catalysts exists in Co3O4 phase. Reduction of Co3O4 occurs in two steps [30]: Co3O4 →3CoO→3Co The first step takes place at 200–300°C [31]. The observed reduction temperature (RT) of Co3O4 decreases from Co/CNTp to Co/CNT1. Trépanier et al. [21] obtained similar effect and attributed it to the opening of CNT channels and cutting of nanotubes. Therefore, there may be a different reason for the RT decrease in Co/CNT1 comparing with Co/CNTp. Several works [21,32] and our TPR results for CNT15 (Fig. 2b) testify that functional groups promote the reduction owing to consumption of hydrogen. Oxidation for 1h reduces particle size and increases pore volume (Fig. 1a) facilitating the reduction. Further support treatment leads to the decrease in pore size and volume and displaces RT to higher values. The second step of Co3O4 reduction (Co0 formation) occurs at 300–450°C and in all catalysts supported on oxidized CNTs this step overlaps with methanation processes. RT grows with the decrease in Co particle sizes increasing the overlapping of CoO reduction and methanation peaks up to Co/CNT9. The small pore size of support is known to inhibit CoO reduction because of the increase in H2O concentration in pores [18,33]. In our case pore size decreases from CNTp to CNT9 and does not change further (Fig. 1a), i.e. it behaves exactly the same way as the RT of Co/CNTs catalysts. The increase of RT with the oxidation of CNT support was also observed in works [22,26]. TEM images of Co/CNTp (Fig. 3 a) demonstrate that Co particles are mostly located on the bends and intertwining of CNTs that is similar to the results in [34]. Co particle size in this sample shows a broad distribution. In the catalyst supported on slightly oxidized CNTs (Fig. 3b) the particle size distribution is significantly narrower, however, large particles (20–70nm) are also seen along with small (∼4–5nm) crystallites. These small crystallites are located both on CNT bends and on the wall defects resulted from the oxidation. In the case of “well oxidized” CNTs (Fig. 3c,d) there are no large particles in TEM images whereas small crystallites are located on both inner and outer surfaces of CNTs. HRTEM images, especially for Co/CNT9 (Fig. 3d), clearly demonstrate that Co particles on the outer surface of CNTs are anchored to the surface cavities formed during the oxidation. Finally, Co/CNT15 catalyst consists of small Co particles supported on highly damaged CNTs (Fig. 3e). The increase in both the number of surface defects and O surface content in CNTs during oxidation leads to the decrease of the standard deviation of the mean Co particle size making the particle size distribution narrower. 3.3 FTS results Catalysts were tested in FTS at 190°C and atmospheric pressure (S3). The highest CO conversion and yield of C5+ fraction are observed for Co/CNT9 (Fig. 4 a). Conversion grows apparently because of the increase in Co dispersion, encapsulation of Co inside channels and cutting of CNTs which promotes lower internal mass transfer limitations for reactants and products [26]. Further decrease of conversion may be attributed to the destruction of support during acid treatment clearly seen in Figs. S1 and 3 . At the same time, Eschemann et al. [22] demonstrated the decrease in CO conversion on Co/CNT after gas-phase oxidation of CNTs in nitric acid vapor and explained this trend by the presence of hexagonal Co in catalysts supported on untreated CNTs. However, comparing to liquid nitric acid treatment in our case, the gas-phase oxidation in their work did not lead to the large number of surface defects responsible for the holding of particles on the CNT surface. Selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons, being the highest for Co/CNTp, decreases in a sequence of Co/CNTp>Co/CNT1>Co/CNT3≈Co/CNT9≈Co/CNT15 (Fig. 4b), i.e. with CNT oxidation. Surface functionalization increases hydrophilic properties of support and water becomes the preferable adsorbate on CNT surface which inhibits the growth of long-chain hydrocarbons [22]. Trépanier et al. [21] explained this trend by the large number of acid groups which increased the amount of hydrogen adsorbed on the catalyst surface and then promoted termination reactions. Our S(C5+) values are in the range of 55–78% which is consistent with the literature data reported for Co/silica catalysts tested at 190°C and atmospheric pressure [35]. 3.4 Co sintering during FTS The observed dependence of conversion and selectivity on the oxidation time of support may be explained by the particle size factor which is considered to be the most significant factor that affects the activity and selectivity of FTS nanocatalysts. Before analyzing the particle size effect, we decided to trace the changes in Co particle size during FTS in order to determine the true diameter at a steady state of FTS and reveal possible sintering process. Catalysts after 70h of FTS were examined by TEM. In all catalysts Co particle size increases after reaction, though to a different extent (Fig. 5 ). The most significant sintering is observed in Co/CNTp (Fig. 5a). For this sample it was impossible to calculate the diameter distribution and the average crystallite size based on TEM images due to the broad range of particle size (1–500nm). For this reason approximate Co particle size for Co/CNTp was estimated from XRD pattern using the maximum at 44.2° corresponded to the dominant phase of cubic Co (Supplementary material, S4). The sintering diagram of Co particles in studied catalyst plotted in Fig. 6 a demonstrates that the most stable Co particles are observed in Co/CNT9. It is interesting that in Co/CNT15 sintering is more pronounced than in Co/CNT3 and Co/CNT9. Oxidation of CNTs for 15h results in their strong destruction (Figs. S1 and 3 e) accompanied by the significant decrease in SBET (Fig. 1a). Apparently it leads to the lower stability of Co particles in the catalyst. Comparison of Figs. 1 a and 6 a allow us to suggest that the specific surface area strongly correlates with the stability of Co particles. Fig. 6b illustrates the effect of support surface geometry on Co sintering. The smooth surface of CNTp does not resist sintering of Co particles. Weak oxidation (CNT1) leads to the surface defects but their number is not enough to hold all Co particles and thus the partial sintering is still observed. In case of the “well-oxidized” surface of Co/CNT3 and Co/CNT9 all Co particles are anchored on the defect sites and this prevents sintering. Excessive CNT oxidation in Co/CNT15 leads to the destruction of the support. The observed sintering of Co particles in this case is comparable to Co/CNT1. We should note that the surface roughness isn’t the only factor which affects particle sintering and the proposed scheme illustrates only the impact of surface geometry on the catalyst stability. 3.5 Particle size, reduction temperature and Co localization effects in FTS on Co/CNT catalysts Co particle size of 4–8nm is supposed to be optimal for the highest activity and selectivity of catalysts on carbon supports, especially on CNTs and CNFs [19,36,37]. On the other hand, particles smaller than 4nm and bigger than 8nm were reported to provide the best catalytic performance [38,39]. Activity, selectivity and reaction turnover frequency (TOF) dependences on the diameter of Co crystallites in used catalysts are plotted in Fig. 7 . Smaller Co particles demonstrate higher activity (Fig. 7a). Similar trend was observed when the particle size was regulated by varying catalyst preparation and calcination technique [39]. In contrast, when Co particle size was varied in a wide range of 2.6–27nm by means of altering the metal content in Co/CNF catalysts, catalytic activity decreased for the particles smaller than 6–8nm [19]. Though this method of Co particle size control is considered to be very effective for catalysts, it leads to different volume concentration of Co. In our previous work [18] it was established that metal volume concentration may significantly affect the catalytic performance especially on carbon supports because of the strong influence of this parameter on the bulk density of catalyst. This effect could affect the results of catalytic activity in [19], where the lowest activity was observed for catalysts with the lowest Co content. However, in our case Co volume concentration is also slightly different in Co/CNTp and catalysts supported on oxidized CNTs. At the same time we showed earlier that even at high Co volume concentration particles smaller than 3nm are unstable and inactive in FTS [18]. Another possible reason for the difference between activity trend in the present study and work [19] is that the average particle size in Fig. 7a relates to the catalysts after FTS contrary to Co particle diameter of reduced catalysts in [19]. Present study shows that Co particle size at steady state of the reaction may significantly differ from that in reduced catalyst. Karimi et al. [36] studied Co/CNTs catalysts with Co particle size of 3–8nm and postulated that the most important factor for high FTS activity and selectivity is the narrowness of particle size distribution rather than the average particle size. In their work the catalyst with Co particles of 8nm and wide size distribution showed worse catalytic performance than the catalyst with narrow size distribution of smaller (4nm) Co crystallites. In our work the highest activity is observed for catalysts supported on strongly oxidized CNTs, in which Co size distribution (see standard deviations from the mean Co particle size in Figs. 3 and 5) is narrower. In the case of oxide support the decrease in Co particle size can lead to the formation of complex oxides which lowers the reducibility and catalytic activity [40]. The observed S(C5+) dependence (Fig. 7b) agrees with low S(C5+) for the catalysts with Co particle size smaller than 6–8nm reported in [19,40,41]. Selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons decreases with crystallite diameter since the chain growth step is very sensitive to the particle size which is attributed to the high hydrogen coverage of small particles [42]. The presence of strongly bonded intermediates was also detected on small Co particles [43]. These intermediates block the active sites to the reactants and reduce TOF. Reaction TOF is plotted in Fig. 7c against Co particle size. No clear dependence is seen in this plot. The exponential dependence from Co particle size is typical for TOF [19,39,44] and may be also applied here. TOF of Co/CNTp catalyst is significantly higher than that of other catalysts. Taking into account the activity of catalysts (Fig. 7a) this result reveals that, although the Co surface atoms in large particles are more effective, their overall number is more important for CO conversion and C5+ yield. Our TOF values are similar to those calculated for Co/CNF and Co/CNT systems with the same Co particle size [19,37,39]. In other works [20,22,26] TOF was higher, probably, due to increase in the reaction pressure, temperature, syngas velocity and conversion. Activity values in the present study are comparable with Bezemer et al. [19] data at 220°C and 1bar for Co/CNF catalyst with similar Co particle size. Our S(C5+) values are high comparing to that obtained at 1bar in [19,37] since the lower temperature was used in our work (190°C). As it was discussed above, the reduction temperature of catalysts increases with the increase of oxidation degree of support and with the decrease of Co particle size. However this produces no negative effect on the catalytic performance. The reduction temperature of 400°C is found to be enough to reduce even very small particles. In [39] the authors also concluded that 400°C is the optimal reduction temperature for the best catalytic performance of Co/CNT catalyst. TEM images show that Co particles are partially located inside CNT channels especially in Co/CNT3 and Co/CNT9 (Fig. 3c,d). There is a controversy in the literature regarding Сo location effect on the catalytic performance. The authors of work [32] showed that Co inside CNT channels demonstrated higher selectivity and similar activity in comparison with Co deposited outside nanotubes. At the same time, Zhu et al. [45] found that catalyst with Co both inside and outside CNTs showed almost the same selectivity as if it had been reduced at 400°C. Iglesia et al. [46] established that hindering of product desorption should lead to their readsorption and higher selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons. In our case catalysts with intratubular Co show the worst C5+ selectivity. Other parameters of catalysts like particle size, CNT defectiveness may also affect the catalytic performance, and even to a greater extent than Co location. Thus, for the studied catalysts it is difficult to isolate the impact of Co location especially due to the presence of both types of Co in each sample. 3.6 Evolution of CNT supports during catalyst preparation and FTS As it was discussed above, some authors [21,22] assumed that the functionalization of CNTs could lead to deterioration of Co/CNT selectivity due to hindering of reactant readsorption and hydrogen association on the support surface. On the other hand oxygen functional groups may decompose during heating or hydrogen treatment [29,47]. Thus, it was interesting to trace the oxygen content on the surface of CNT support after calcination, reduction and FTS reaction. Co/CNT9 catalyst was chosen for this purpose. In order to remove Co species the catalyst was washed by HCl after calcination (N2-CNT), reduction (H2-CNT) and catalytic test (FTS-CNT) and then studied by XPS. Total oxygen content on the CNT surface expectedly decreases after each stage of treatment (Fig. 8 a). Only ∼30% of initial oxygen remains on the surface by the time of FTS. CNTs in used catalyst contain ∼23% of initial oxygen. The decrease in oxygen content after the impregnation stage was also detected in Pt/C catalyst [48]. Deconvolution of C1s and O1s XPS spectra allows us to trace which groups are gone at each stage. At the calcination stage (N2-CNT) the decomposition of carboxyl groups is predominantly observed (Fig. 8b), which agrees with the reported result for thermal treatment of oxidized CNTs [49]. Decomposition of carboxyl groups at this stage contradicts XPS data for Pt/CNF catalysts [50]. It was found that Pt deposition led to the decomposition of phenol groups. Such a difference can be explained by the adsorption of Pt atoms on R3COR groups in contrast to Co atoms, which are predominantly adsorbed on carboxylic sites. At the same time, titration in [50] revealed disappearing of carboxyl groups during calcination and reduction, though the results of C1s XPS peak deconvolution are not presented in this paper. The decrease in content of all functional groups is observed at the reduction stage (H2-CNT), with C O groups (hydroxyl, ether) being decomposed faster. Reduction of functionalities at this stage is also observed in TPR curves (Fig. 2b). XPS data demonstrate the slight decrease in number of single-bonded O atoms, though the hydrogenation of carboxyl groups should increase the number of phenols and decrease the number carboxyl groups. However, H2 could migrate from metal to support and promote the decomposition of functional groups [50]. Apparently, only a small number of groups are hydrogenated and more are decomposed as a result of thermal treatment at 400°C. Finally, after FTS stage only C O and O C O groups remain on the CNT surface and the number of C O groups is more than that of O C O groups according to C1s XPS spectrum. Residue of O C O groups is explained by some undecomposed lactones or anhydrides. O1s spectra deconvolution indicates the presence of both single- and double-bonded oxygen atoms that indirectly points on quinone groups which are also stable at high temperatures as well as ethers or phenols [51]. Raman investigation of these samples demonstrates the decrease in the defectiveness of CNT9 after calcination of catalyst (Fig. 8c). During this process Co nitrate decomposes, releasing NO2 which may oxidize highly defective sites on CNT surface making it smoother. Further treatment of catalyst in both hydrogen and syngas increases ID/IG ratio. SBET and pore volume increase after CNT9 calcination and reduction (Table 1 ) but decrease after FTS. Such trend may be explained by the comparison of pore volume distribution of CNT9 support after different stages of catalyst preparation and catalytic test (Fig. 9 ). Micropores widen after calcination as a result of oxidation by NO2 and hence the number of mesopores (R ∼9–17nm) increases. Further H2 treatment of Co/CNT9 leads to the appearance of pores with the radius of 6–8nm but no increase in the volume of pores of 9–17nm is observed. This change is apparently a result of etching of CNT surface by Co particles in hydrogen flow at high temperature. TPR curves of CNT supports and catalysts reveal that methanation of CNTs shifts to lower temperature in the presence of Co particles. Thus Co crystallites could promote the formation of cavities at their locations. Indeed, TEM study of the support after H2 treatment reveals these cavities (Fig. S5). Their formation also leads to more edge carbon atoms which increases ID/IG ratio in Raman spectrum after reduction (Fig. 8b). Similar cavities were also found in our previous work [8] during the TEM study of reduced and additionally annealed Co/CNT catalyst. Pore blocking by wax during FTS is the main reason for SBET and V decrease after catalytic test. It is worth to note that the reduction time of Co/CNT catalysts should be decreased and the temperatures not higher than 400°C have to be used since the increase in both the reduction time and temperature may lead to the strong destruction of support. The results of the study allow revealing the role of the functional groups and structure defects on the surface of CNTs in the stabilization of Co particles during the preparation and catalytic test of Co/CNTs catalysts. First of all, at the impregnation stage, the great number of functionalities promotes the uniform distribution of Co nitrate over CNT surface due to Co2+ anchoring similar to Ni/CNF catalyst in [52] where Ni(H2O)6 2+ ions were adsorbed on carboxyl groups. Since oxygen groups are localized near surface defects, no sintering of Co oxide particles is observed during the calcination despite the decomposition of carboxyls and the decrease in oxygen content. During the reduction Co particles etch the CNT surface improving their own stabilization. Residual oxygen groups (quinines/ethers/phenols) along with the defects may also prevent Co sintering in the catalytic reaction as it was observed for Pt/CNF catalyst [50]. Thus, metal dispersion depends on the surface oxygen content. At the same time, catalytic stability is more dependent on surface geometry than on the total number of functional groups. 4 Conclusions CNT surface was tuned by the oxidation in nitric acid for different time. Study of the oxidation kinetics of CNTs revealed the existence of optimal degree of oxidation which results in the maximum of specific surface area, pore size, defectiveness and oxygen content. Further treatment leads either to deterioration of these parameters or to the destruction of CNT structure. Broadening of Co XRD peak and displacement of reduction peaks in TPR curves indicate significant changes in the size of cobalt oxide particles and pore parameters of supports. HRTEM images confirm the decrease of Co particle size with the oxidation of support. These Co particles are located both inside and outside CNTs and stabilized by defects in CNTs generated by oxidation. Catalytic tests in FTS showed that the best CO conversion and C5+ yield are achieved on Co catalyst supported on CNTs with the highest degree of functionalization, the highest specific surface area and the lowest Co particle size. Although Co surface atoms in large particles are more effective, their overall number in studied catalysts is more important for CO conversion and C5+ yield enhancement. Post-catalytic TEM study revealed that the degree of Co sintering correlates with the specific surface area of CNTs, with the highest sintering being observed for Co supported on pristine CNTs. Oxygen content on the surface of oxidized CNTs and their structure were traced during the catalyst preparation and catalytic test. Significant changes in the content of functional groups and etching of CNTs were observed during reduction. Reduction of Co/CNT catalysts should be performed rapidly and at temperature not higher than 400°C. Though metal dispersion depends on the surface oxygen content, the stability of metal particles is more dependent on surface geometry of support than on the total amount of functional groups. Residual oxygen groups, left on the surface after calcination and reduction, may also play a role in the prevention of Co sintering during catalytic reaction but this role is less important than the surface geometry of CNT support. coredata.dc:description: CNT oxidation, Co/CNT preparation and transformation of both catalyst and support in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) were thoroughly studied. CNTs functionalized by nitric acid for 1–15h were used as supports for Co catalysts for FTS at 190°C and atmospheric pressure. Co supported on CNTs with the highest specific surface area and oxygen content showed the highest activity and C5+ yield. According to TEM results after 70h of FTS this catalyst was the most stable to Co sintering due to the large number of surface defects and oxygen groups on a support surface combined with the preserved integrity of CNTs. Activity of catalysts increased and selectivity to C5+ decreased when the particle size diminished from 26.5 to 4.3nm. Study of the evolution of CNT support revealed that most of the carboxylic groups decomposed at calcination. Etching of support surface during the catalyst reduction and partial pore blocking after FTS were detected.
coredata.dc:title: Co catalysts supported on oxidized CNTs: Evolution of structure during preparation, reduction and catalytic test in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis
